ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: I went to the lab in-person, but there was the option to be fully remote.
Almost all of the labs were in person. Appropriate social distancing was maintained.
Virtual lab when required by Yale COVID restrictions
There were also virtual components of the lab when we couldn't come in.
In-person meetings were optional, but most students went in person. Some labs were exclusively virtual at the beginning.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to make a bug collection. Learned the names of so many types of bugs, as well as ecology and behavior.
I learned all I needed to about ID'ing and collecting bugs.

I gained a truly remarkable amount of knowledge for insects, arthropods, and the processes for catching, pinning, and identifying such species. Such knowledge, while at times overwhelming, was made accessible through frequent handouts and guides, as well as flexibility on quizzes and lab expectations as the semester progressed.

In this course I learned the foundations of classifying terrestrial arthropods, the methods of collecting and preserving them, and their evolutionary significance. We participated in field work as a class and independently to collect specimens, and were given the tools and instruction to pin and dry, or preserve in ethyl alcohol the various specimens we collected. We also had access to specimens from the Peabody museum as well as those kept in the Sterling Chemistry Laboratory. This course provided numerous opportunities to gain hands-on experience in the field of entomology.
I learned a lot about collecting arthropods and how collections and done and maintained. I also learned a lot about different arthropods and many different orders and families.
Learned about the phylogenetic arthropod tree, learned how to dissect, classify, preserve, and pin insects. We learned and practiced various collection methods.
Learned all about Arthropods. This lab supplemented the lecture
Understanding the anatomy and classification system of arthropods.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was a lot of work, as making an entire collection required a lot of time outside of class, but it was super fun. There were weekly quizzes, which required a decent amount of studying to prepare for in order to memorize a lot.
This course is a lot of work.

This lab course was one of the best I have ever taken at Yale, and I can only imagine it would be far better in a typical year. The course this year suffered from COVID restrictions preventing us from visiting Florida to capture insects, as would occur in a typical semester. As such, there was a higher reliance on quizzes and lower reliance on the insect collection portion of the curriculum, which is understandable yet disappointing (although not Dr. Wells's fault!). However, every attempt was made by Dr. Wells and Sarah, the TF, to reduce stress, up to and including dropping a quiz, making the quiz in election week virtual to reduce anxiety, changing the requirements for bug collection throughout the semester, and offering frequent outings and office hours to collect and help prepare bugs. I would point out the course's organization as a slight weakness: the first week of insect ID, for example, we had to differentiate between six orders, while the material on the last week covered four orders but dozens of families. As such, I would recommend a more even distribution of work per week to help out. Besides that, I experienced nothing but happiness in this class, and felt it to be one of the highlights at my time at Yale.

The hands-on interaction of this course made it very engaging and gave inherent practical application to all that we learned. Class field trips to various locations to collect arthropods enhanced the experience of this class as well.

The professor and teaching staff were clearly really passionate about the subject and did their best to make it engaging. I also appreciated the flexibility and things such as the bug blogs since we couldn't do as much collecting this semester. However, in general with a couple exceptions, the quizzes were really hard. There were too many families to memorize, and I ended up putting far more work into the lab than the main class itself.

I loved this class and think it was taught very well. The class gave me a sense of community during the pandemic and both the professor and TA were very friendly, personable, approachable, and helpful. The quizzes were fair and the collection project was very fun.
Great course. Creating the insect collections is awesome

Strengths: I liked that we were able to be in person, and I really enjoyed the field trips we took. I thought the weekly quizzes, while relatively work-heavy, were a great way to keep us on top of the content. 
Weaknesses: I wish we had a couple more opportunities to collect insects as a class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It would probably be hard to do this lab fully remote, as it was very helpful to get hands on help in identification and processing of the bugs.
They handled everything well.

As mentioned, the reorganization of this course in response to COVID-19 was unprecedented and mostly beneficial, although I am saddened to have missed the opportunity to visit Florida. Dr. Wells did the best she could despite that, and changed the curriculum to be something that I would still consider fair, enjoyable, and as close to the full experience as possible given the circumstances. Her options to assist virtual learners, as well as students who took a little longer to pin insects, were truly remarkable, and I applaud her flexibility on the quiz material (such as dropping a quiz and providing extra credit on most). Because of this, I would say that this course dealt with the restrictions of COVID-19 very well.
As this course was taught in person per usual, I assume that the format was very similar if not the same as during normal years.

Being able to go into lab was nice, but the structures online were also good. The photos/videos of the bugs during the final quiz and exam were very useful. It would've been nice to have an open book final like the main class, just since there were so many different families to memorize. Overall, I thought the professor was accommodating and did her best to listen to students and move things around due to the pandemic.

I took this class in-person, so it felt mostly like a normal class. A few remote students took the lab virtually, and at the end of the semester we all took the final virtually. The TA uploaded high-quality pictures and videos of arthropod specimens for us to classify on Canvas. The videos were the next-best-thing from seeing the specimens in person.
Very accommodating to students during this time

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend it if you are an E&EB major and have to take an organismal diversity lab or if you are very interested in bugs and have extra free time in your schedule to devote to this class. But, be wary it is a lot of work for 0.5 credits, but also a lot of fun.
Yes, very useful for ecologists.

I would recommend this course wholeheartedly to an EEB student, and even to non-EEB students with an otherwise light workload. Marta is the nicest professor I have ever had at Yale, period. She cares so much about each of her students, especially those in her lab, and is full of so much energy: from her collection of bug ties to her cricket-themed ringtone, it is clear that she radiates passion for insects, and by extension, any student in her course. She truly wants each and every person to succeed, and makes herself available, even by phone, to give advice on how to make the best collections possible. This course is time intensive, and will require you to attend outside of the weekly lab hours in order to complete a collection if you are not well-versed with the practices of a biology lab going in. I estimate I spent around 10-15 non-lab hours pinning insects, and another 10 or so catching them. However, you get to catch bugs! Many comparisons to Animal Crossing notwithstanding, I felt incredibly excited when I stumbled upon a mantis, monarch, and rare caterpillar to add to my collection, and it is easy to get wrapped up in the fieldwork. I can't imagine how more exciting it must be to do the same in Florida, although I imagine that would be much more time-intensive. Thus, if you have the time and want to live out your dreams of becoming a humble bug collector, I recommend this course. Just know that you may need to spend more time on it than you think.

I would highly recommend this course to any student interested in entomology, or simply anyone with an interest in collecting arthropods. You will learn how to classify all sorts of arthropods, and get hands-on experience and immediate practical applications to what you learn. This class was so much fun!
I would if they're genuinely interesting in bugs and arthropods and collecting, because you get lots of good hands on experience.
Absolutely! This class was so fun and engaging, and was a great supplement to the lecture.
Yes very fun lab
Yes, this was my favorite lab course at Yale!
